Your First C Program


Introduction to C

C is a programming language created in 1972. It is still widely used today and is often taught in university courses pertaining to low-level programming and systems programming due to its versatile environment and ability to work with many types of machines.

Operating systems like Windows were created using C, and other popular programming languages such as C++, C#, Java, JavaScript, Python, and PHP were influenced by the contributions of C. Today, C is regarded as one of the best programming languages to date, ranking #5 on Northeastern University's Graduate rankings on best programming languages, as well as having an average salary of about $97,000. More information is listed here!

In this tutorial, we will be using C to program a very simple "Hello world" program. Although the steps may be intimidating for beginners, users will eventually pick up the pace and will learn the basics of C very quickly. 'Hello world' is universally the first program everyone writes when learning a new language, so if this is your first time learning C or any programming language, you're in the right place.

Without further ado, let's get started!


Opening a terminal

To set up a terminal, you may either use an online IDE, or integrated development environment, or download a terminal such as Ubuntu. Both options work for this tutorial; it is recommended that you download your own personal terminal if you plan to create future projects, as online IDEs are not as reliable for saving your work.

Download instructions for Ubuntu:
Windows
Mac

Basics of Linux

Ubuntu, like many other types of terminals, are open-source softwares that run on Linux and Unix. Linux operates as a kernel and is the most popular open-source source of software collaboration, so much so that almost all smartphones are operated on Linux, and the majority of our cloud infrastructure was built on Linux.

Much of the terminal interface can be decided by the user, or administrator depending on who gets certain permissions. Here are some simple commands to get you comfortable with Linux:

  • ls
    • lists all present files in the directory
  • cd
    • changes directory
  • mkdir
    • creates a new directory/path
  • rmdir
    • removes a directory/path
  • pwd
    • returns path of the current directory
  • more
    • views the contents of a file or multiple files
  • rm
    • removes a particular file or set of similar files
  • touch
    • creates a file, does not redirect to any text editor
  • cp
    • copies a file contents
  • mv
    • moves a file into different directories
  • echo
    • repeats the desired keyword or phrase that user inputs
  • cat
    • repeats file contents in plain text, concatenated
  • grep
    • search for expressions in a file


More information on how to use Linux can be seen here.


Using nano to edit text

We left out one more important command: nano. This is the command you use to enter the nano text-editor. The instructions are simple: nano {filename} Filenames that run on C code will have the filename extension .c

Including standard input or output

When creating a new C program, always preface your code with the following statement: #include <stdio.h>

The statement above indicates that the program you're writing is applicable for input and output methods, such as typing into a program (input) or reading the contents back from the program (output). In this tutorial, we want the terminal to print our statement upon execution. In other words, we want the output.

It is good practice to keep using #include <stdio.h> when creating C files, as this lessens the chance of receiving an error or exception when compiling your program.


Print statements

A simple print statement can be made using the following: printf(); (Don't forget the semicolons at the end!)
Within the brackets, we can insert whatever text we want, enclosed in quotation marks. It is also useful to consider escape characters.

One escape character that is especially useful is \nThis indicates a newline escape character, where text is directed to the line after the escape character is declared.

To learn more about other escape characters, click here.


In our tutorial, we want to print "Hello world", that's it. Therefore, we can type the following: printf("Hello world"); We can also utilize our newline character by typing printf("Hello world\n"); This is also useful when the terminal finishes and the prompt line does not interfere with the contents printed. Try this yourself.


Methods and return statements

We cannot simply print a statement alone. In order for this to work, we need to enclose our code within at least one function, the main function.
Typically, the main method may look like this: int main() { } Or this: void main() { }

The only real difference between the two is that int requires that an integer value returns at the end of the function while void returns nothing, and no return statement needs to be explicitly created.

Every return statement, such as the case with our function, may look like this: return 0; The 0 returns something; there is no significance other than the fact that we have an integer to pass through once our program is done.

In our program, we will be using int main() { } to enclose our print statement. It is up to you whether we need a return statement or not (spoiler: we need it).


Saving your work

By the time you've reached this part of the tutorial, your code should look like this: #include <stdio.h>

int main() {
 printf("Hello world\n");
 return 0;
} If not, check back to see which parts you're missing.

Once you're finished, using nano, all you need to do is Ctrl + S to save your work. To exit out of nano, simply type in Ctrl + X. If you need to cancel, for whatever reason, you can cancel your work using Ctrl + C. Depending on your save state, nano may ask to save your work. All yes and no options are to be answered with 'Y' and 'N', respectively.


Executing your Program

Last but not least, after all the hard work, we want to execute our program. Let's assume that our filename is something like test.c, and we want the executable, which is what we use to execute the program itself, to be named test. Therefore, we need to type: gcc -o test test.c

A new executable file will appear in the directory you created your file (by default, there are instructions for later on how to create executables into specific directories). The last step is to ensure that the executable works with: ./test The  ./  signals to the computer that the executable is ready to, well, execute.

Congratulations

You've completed your first C program. Cheers to you! I wish you well on your next steps to learning how to program in C.
